pgNbr=6 Disaster Relief During 1998, Philip Morris contributed more than $1.8 million to assist 32 disaster relief efforts in 16 countries around the globe, providing funds, food, water and volunteer services. In the United States, we responded to floods, hurricanes and other disasters in a dozen states from California to New York. Internationally, we contributed to relief efforts in areas from Central America, Argentina and Brazil to Central Europe, China and the Philippines. Employee Volunteerism Philip Morris employees continued to give back to their communities through a variety of volunteer activities, including serving food in soup kitchens, tutoring children, building homes for the needy and teaching adults to read. Through the Philip Morris Employee Fund and Kraft Employee Fund-managed by committees of employees representing a cross-section of the Philip Morris family - - employees pledged $2.8 million in 1998, to which the companies will add more than $1.35 million in 1999, for distribution to more than 100 charities and civic programs. Commitment to Diversity In 1998, we continued working at every level to strengthen and promote cultural diversity throughout the Philip Morris workplace and among the vendors who serve us. The percentages of women and of people of color among our U.S. employees, and among our cadre of senior executives, have grown steadily since TK. pgNbr=8 Beer Underlying income at Miller Brewing Company continued to grow, increasing to $xxx million. However, Miller's overall performance in 1998 proved disappointing. Domestic shipment volume was down 1.8% and market share declined one point, driven by continued intense competition and the absence of pricing advantages. Domestic volume for Miller Lite fell, but remained above 19961evels. Volume for Miller Genuine Draft was also down. However, shipments of Miller High Life grew slightly. Toward the end of the year, Miller took steps to improve its advertising campaigns for both Miller Lite and Miller Genuine Draft. Both Icehouse and Foster's posted double-digit volume gains, for the second year in a row. Within the Molson brand family, Miller focused on the Molson Canadian brand, which also saw double-digit volume growth. Miller entered into a five-year agreement to contract-brew Pabst and certain other S&P Company brands. The contract should result in additional income that Miller can reinvest in its business. Miller also strengthened its distribution network by introducing a new contract to improve retail execution and increase distributors' commitment to Miller's product line International sales of Miller products held steady at 2.6 million barrels, with licensee and affiliate volume continuing to offset a planned decline in exports. During the year, Miller took several innovative steps to improve its business. As a result of increased efficiencies in the way our breweries handle glass bottles, Miller was able to successfully introduce an 18-pack longneck bottle, a major new package for Miller Lite, Miller Genuine Draft and Miller Genuine Draft Light. In a beer-industry first, Miller introduced a special new recyclable plastic bottle for Miller Lite, Miller Genuine Draft and Icehouse beers in six cities across the country. The new packaging provides the taste, freshness and shelf life of a glass bottle, with the convenience of cans, in response to strong interest from beer consumers. Although Miller had a difficult year, it is addressing the challenges ahead with creative solutions to stabilize its business and deliver better growth in the future. pgNbr=11 International Food 1998 marked the beginning of renewed progress in our international food business. Although volume declined due to economic conditions in Russia and Brazil as well as soft coffee markets in Europe in the first half of the year, we saw good gains in the established markets of the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, the Benelux countries, Norway, Denmark and Australia. Importantly, most of our major European coffee, confectionery and grocery brands showed share growth in the second half of the year. Underlying income of $x.x billion was slightly below 19971evels, due primarily to increased brand-building marketing investments in Europe, lower coffee volume and the Russian economic crisis. The comparison of underlying results excludes, most significantly, the impact of two 1997 items: charges to realign the business and the gain from our sale of ice cream businesses in Brazil. Coffee volume was down due to the impact of high commodity-driven retail prices in the beginning of the year. However, declines in retail prices encouraged recoveries in most of our major markets in the second half of the year, and full-year volume was up in the established markets of Italy and Austria and in the developing markets of Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary. We gained share in the roast and ground coffee category in Germany, our largest market, benefiting in part from marketing initiatives for Meisterrostung, our value brand. In addition, we saw share gains for premium Carte Noire and.7acques Vabre roast and ground coffees in France, Gevalia roast and ground coffee in Sweden and soluble Kenco and Maxwell House coffees in the United Kingdom. Although confectionery volume was lower, principally as a result of market conditions in Russia and pricing in Germany, share for our key chocolate brand Milka grew in France, Italy and Spain, aided in part by successful promotions and new products. In Germany, a 25`' anniversary celebration of the Mflka brand symbol, the "Milka Cow," strengthened consumer and trade awareness, and we launched several new Milka line extensions. In our Central European markets, we introduced line extensions for Prince Polo in Poland and Korona in the Ukraine, and we launched Sugus in Romania. We also expanded Forte and 3-Bit confectioneries throughout the region. In Brazil, our Lacta products gained share despite a sharp market decline. Volume grew in our cheese and grocery business on gains in many markets, including Italy, Spain, the United Kingdom, the Middle East, Africa, Australia and China. Especially strong volume growth in the United Kingdom was fueled by successful promotions for Dairylea Dunkers and the introduction of Dairylea Lunchables. We also launched Kraft Lunchables in Germany and expanded Tang powdered soft drinks in Romania and Turkey. Philadelphia Brand cream cheese continued to grow strongly, with volume and share gains in several markets including Italy, Spain and Australia. In addition, Estrella and Maarud snacks gained volume in Scandinavia. However, powdered soft drink volume declined in Latin America, due primarily to the impact on our beverage business of a price war between carbonated soft drink manufacturers in Argentina. pgNbr=12 Corporate Citizenship We define ourselves at the Philip Morris family of companies by our deep involvement in the communities where we live and work, and by our strong support for programs that serve undeniable human needs. We have had a prominent corporate citizenship program for more than 40 years, because it's the right thing to do. Following are highlights of our 1998 corporate citizenship activities. Hunger Combating hunger is our primary grant-making priority. Philip Morris remains one of the largest corporate funders of hunger-relief programs throughout the United States, and we have given more than $170 million in cash grants and food product donations to hunger programs around the world since 1990. In 1998, we launched a national awareness campaign in the United States to encourage others to help fight hunger. We also supported overseas hunger programs in a wide range of countries, including the United Kingdom, Hungary, Bulgaria, Lithuania, Australia and the Philippines. Our national "Helping the Helpers" U.S. program supports organizations that provide direct services to people in need. The program includes Senior Helpings, our partnership with the National Meals on Wheels Foundation to improve meals for the homebound elderly across America and overseas... Fighting Hunger, a pioneering Miller program that forms public-private partnerships to address critical hunger relief needs. .. Community Kitchens, Foodchain's unique program to train unemployed and homeless people for the foodservice industry while providing meals for the hungry... Native American Hunger Program, in partnership with First Nations Development Institute, to address hunger on rural Native American reservations; and Kraft's Fresh Produce Initiative, through which Kraft and Philip Morris are providing $7.5 million to help food banks provide some 500 million servings of fresh fruit and vegetables a year to people who need them most. As one of the largest corporate contributors to HIV/AIDS programs, we have focused many of our efforts on the importance of nutrition. In 1998, our Positive Helpings Program, developed in partnership with the National AIDS Fund, helped fill the nutritional needs of more than TK people with HIV/AIDS. Domestic Violence Philip Morris is a leading corporate supporter of national programs to help victims of domestic violence and to raise public awareness of the impact domestic violence can have in the workplace. In 1998, our $2 million commitment to the fight against domestic violence included "Doors of Hope," a $1 million program developed in partnership with the national Network to End Domestic Violence Fund. Through this program, we provided grants to 132 organizations in a1150 states, focusing on direct services such as food, shelter, clothing, counseling and job training, as well as outreach, training and awareness programs. 1/14/99 draft: Corp.
